area_name: t. Mya to the East End

content.description: Start in a pit. Climb on big holds to a ledge in an alcove. Stem up to a crack with good pro. Climb to a large scary rock under the roof. Climb the crack above the roof (crux) to a tree belay.
content.protection: Good protection in the blue metolius to red camalot range. Nuts also work well.
content.location: Just left of the unmistakable tiered roof cracks of "Sage and Whiskey," which shares an anchor with this route.

content.description: On the left side of the small canyon behind East Pillar.  Starts with a robust mantle onto a ledge 8 ft up.  Then works up the corner, thru a squeeze past a block (crux).  Short route but it's sustained.
content.protection: Mostly small/medium cams and a couple questionable micronuts.  DO NOT place gear around the golden tablet that is so key to your right hand about mid-height.  #3 or 4 Camalot protects the squeeze move nicely.
content.location: Head up into the small box canyon behind East Pillar, and look up to your left.  The route is the corner under the big "diving board" block above.

content.description: The left of the two options on the south (or southwest) face of East Pillar.  Start 8' left of the maple tree and climb through the prominent V groove, then follow a pair of vertical seams to the top.
content.protection: Almost no gear, but it WOULD take a blue BigBro.  Revised to add: in the absence of a BigBro, you could get a small cam or two in the crack that runs up and left of this line, just above the wide horizontal.  That will be a few feet left of the crux moves through the V slot.  The upper face is going to be virtually unprotected in any event.
content.location: 8 ft left of the tree on the left side of the free standing East Pillar.  You can scramble up the back side or hike the trail 2 minutes further east.

content.description: A nice face climb in the "Gunks style" i.e. big moves between good stances at each horizontal.  Nice straight line with opportunities to show off your problem solving skills.
content.protection: Totally G rated if you have a normal rack. I placed from a #1 Met. TCU up to a #3 Camalot (but I could have used the 2 Camalot instead).  Also a few small nuts.
content.location: 25 ft right of the flaring V chimney (not described on MP, but a decent, if awkward 5.5 line) and 10 ft left of a large square boulder stack (Bro Crack starts behind this stack).  See photo.

content.description: Climb the steep, sheer face just L of where the boulderers have the wall chalked up under a large ceiling.  The crux is moving R into the hanging dihedral; two ways to do this.  IME either one is significantly harder than the 5.10 rating given in the Wilson guidebook.
content.protection: Bolts directly above the route, but beware of sharp edges.
content.location: Start just L of the arete.

content.description: The steep face just left of East Chimney.  Climb right-facing features up the center of the face, making your way to the offwidth at the top.  I suspect taller climbers will have an easier time on this.
content.protection: TR from trees and gear above (look under the small black birch for a 4" crack)
content.location: Around right of East Pillar's main face, about 10' left of E.P. Chimney.  The offwidth is easily spotted from a few yards further right on the trail.

content.description: The large, left-leaning corner that starts at laurel bushes about 30 ft L of the Mya wall.
content.protection: Adequate gear. Watch for the rope-pinching crack at the top.

content.description:
Start in an obvious chimney, negotiate the left-leaning exit, and make a few steep finger-crack moves to finish. 

  The climbing is varied and quality;  it's a good 5.5 lead for 5.8 leaders.
content.protection:
You'll want at least one piece of 3" or larger, though there are additional options in the chimney. 

  To TR, you'd need some very long slings;  the closest tree to the topout is quite dead.
content.location: Between Hugh's Roof and Bro Crack.

content.description: On the "front side" of the pillar look for a steep crack in a left facing corner on the upper half of the face.  The lower half is semi-blankish.  The upper part is delightful jam & layback, while the lower part is serious (tricky and sparse gear), devious, and a bit reachy.
content.protection: Micro cams and ball nuts if you fancy leading this, then normal cams and big nuts on the upper crack.  The TR anchor is easy enough if that's your choice.
content.location: The climb is directly above the trail.  You can walk off on the trail to climber's right, it's about 50 yd to the end of the cliff.

content.description: Just beyond the Pillar is a boulder-filled chimney.  Something to warm up on in that area, but no classic.  Better than "Stacked" however.
content.protection: PG, normal gear, trees atop for anchor.
content.location: about 30 feet beyond the front face of East Pillar, right where the trail bumps into a 3-4' boulder that you need to climb over or around.

content.description: A good line with a tricky crux at the overhang.  Start at the maple tree and pass the overhang at its widest point.
content.protection: TR only so far, no gear on the lower face.
content.location: On the left side of the pillar.   You can scramble up the back side or hike the trail 2 minutes further east.

content.description: Start at a ledge behind a tree;  climb either side of the cracks, and get yourself around a protruding boulder.
content.location: Between Hugh's Roof and the obvious Flaring Vee chimney.

content.description: A really fun route that is easy to miss as you explore PK's east end.  Layback the crack in the starting cave to a ceiling, traverse left then blast up the crack.  Alternatively, start on the left of the block and climb the arete up to the crack.
content.protection: Supplement a normal rack with at least a couple pieces (cams or Big Bros) in the 4 to 7 inch range, and it's G rated.
content.location: Starts in a cave behind a boulder stack about 50' L of East Pillar.  Approach the cave from the right or tunnel through from the base of Rainy Daze.

content.description: From the base of the large Jitterbug corner, climb up right to the left-pointing flake (5.7), step L to the outside corner, surmount the overhang, and climb the steep upper face just L of the arete.  A great powerful crux sequence that is harder than 10c to figure out.
content.protection: TR only.  Don't anchor off the pitch pine.  Pad the top edge.
content.location: 30 feet Left of the Mya wall

pathTokens: t. Mya to the East End

content.description: Just past the route Mya is a beautiful stretch of cliff with enormous features.  Lots of good climbing out here and it's usually cool and shady.  East Pillar is the free standing pillar 3-400 ft right of the last routes in the Wilson PK guidebook.  The area is also marked by the very triangular Hugh's Roof.
